Situation1: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the wall, my heart thumping faster as the minutes ticked by. The national continuing education webinar was in full swing, and the speaker was finally addressing the new guidelines for hypertension—something I needed to master to better serve my patients and keep my license current. My notepad was already half-filled with scribbles and questions, but my mind kept drifting to the reminder on my phone: the polling place down the street would close in less than two hours. There was a ballot measure that could change the way our block handled traffic and safety, something my neighbors and I had debated for weeks. As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to cast my vote, to be part of the decision that would shape our daily lives. But as a pharmacist, I knew missing this session could mean falling behind, risking my professional standing and the trust my patients placed in me. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I found myself frozen, torn between my duty to my profession and my duty to my community.
